information: A survey in Argentina conducted between April 28 and 30, 2025, by D'Alessio IROL/Berensztein indicated growing wear on Javier Milei's government. The survey showed his positive image has decreased to 44%, while his negative image has increased to 52%, for a net differential of -8%. 52% of respondents believe the economic situation is worse than the previous year. The evaluation of his government is divided, with 50% rating it as good and 48% as bad. Security Minister Patricia Bullrich has the highest positive image in the cabinet at 47%, as insecurity is the main social concern for 72% of respondents.

forecast.status_quo_outcome: Yes (Milei 61% vs Sheinbaum 60% per the background at question time)
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: By late June, Morning Consult shows Sheinbaum at ~60–63% while Milei has slipped to the mid–50s to ~58%, or even a tie. Any Sheinbaum honeymoon persistence plus modest deterioration in Argentine sentiment pushes her at/above Milei. A tie resolves No.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Milei sustains or regains a clear edge (e.g., 60–62% vs Sheinbaum ~58–60%) due to visible economic stabilization headlines (inflation deceleration, FX stability, reform passage/market rally), while Sheinbaum dips on a security/energy/governance stumble that briefly knocks a few points off her approval.
forecast.rationale:
- Arbiter: Morning Consult global leader approval. A single comparison when Metaculus checks on/after June 28; ties count as No.
- Status quo: Milei holds a 1-pt edge (61 vs 60). Good practice is to overweight the status quo. However, the margin is razor-thin and ties go to No, so the bar for a Yes is effectively “Milei strictly above Sheinbaum on that check.”
- Trend signals: The assistant’s cited Argentina poll (D’Alessio IROL/Berensztein, Apr 28–30) shows Milei’s image weakening (44% positive, 52% negative, net -8). That is not Morning Consult, but it aligns with plausible headwinds from austerity and social costs. Morning Consult’s series tends to move slowly but can reflect medium-term sentiment shifts.
- Mexico baseline: New presidents often enjoy a honeymoon. AMLO’s Morning Consult numbers were persistently high; Sheinbaum’s have been robust so far (background puts her at 60%). It’s reasonable she stays near 60 through late June absent a shock.
- Argentina baseline: Milei’s approval has been comparatively high at times, but 2025 brings trade-offs as stabilization pain bites. A modest downtrend into the high-50s by late June seems more likely than an uptick.
- Net: With a 1-point starting edge for Milei but headwinds and a tie counting as No, the balance favors No. Still, a Yes is very plausible if June headlines favor Milei (reforms/inflation) or if Sheinbaum hits a transient rough patch.
- Why not higher: Tie-to-No rule, Milei’s recent negative momentum, and Sheinbaum’s likely honeymoon stability.
- Why not lower: Morning Consult can keep leaders’ approvals quite sticky; Milei could hold ~60 if macro indicators improve. Small week-to-week noise could keep him a tick ahead.
- Updates:
  • Upward (toward Yes): Clear Argentine macro wins (notably visible in headlines), legislative victories, an uptick in MC showing Milei > Sheinbaum by ≥2 pts in mid-June; or a Mexico shock (security/blackouts/scandal) that knocks Sheinbaum below 60.
  • Downward (toward No): Continued Argentine social unrest or worsening living-standards data; MC prints Milei ≤ Sheinbaum or a tie in early/mid-June; Sheinbaum holding steady ≥60.
